Edward Banks

PRESIDENT Johnson TELLS
NNPA DELEGATES THAT He
STANDS ON HIS PAST RECORD

There has been a great deal Of publicity
concerning the lack Of city government inter-
estS in the southside. Less than tho weeks
ago Mayor Milton Graham and the City Cos1,s- "a
Gil limited residents Of the south area to meet
with them. .7o1


The meeting sOas attended by only a mere 5Hs
HANDFUL, about go came. Where weYe the sd sd
throngS of persons sOho said they weye dis qans1
satisfied with the city council and the mayor?
Where sOeTe the hundreds sOlaO sOeye going to
press for more city sponsored facilities, in :
chtding recreation centeys, libraries and PACED
streets?


Surely more persons could haze been present
at such an important meeting. Participation TN
such meetings is necessary If the sossthside is
to assume its role as an active party of city ot
affairs.


Let us hope that those persons buyboytedly .Ir
interest," in the s0uthside community mill be prs
present at any future meetings Of this magni-
tude.

This week the required number Of states
ratified the amendment which ended the bOH
tax leUied in several southern states. The
poll tax had been one Of the means to discOuY-
age Negroes from becoming eligible to OOte.
Although the payment required aUas not exor-
bitant, it kept many from even trying to reg
lister.


A far greater curb on votinzg of Negroes in
the South is the Hteyacy test program. There
seems to be concrete evidence that different
and more rigid tests are applied to Negroes
seeking to register than to whites.


AbOhshi'lg Of the boll tax mill hardly in
crease the numbers of qualified Negro UOteys.
There wlH be many legal suits filed before
the Obsta cles to registration are overcome.


The end Of the poll tax should however,
arouse the voti'ag interests Of all Negroes
Who haze not eOey been required to pay poll
tax or face a HteYacy test.


EveYy person should remember that many
thousands haze died in order to assure the
vOtinlg rights of their children and grand
children.


Poll taxes haze ended but let's improve our
action at the voteYs' registration aOindouOs.
Also, let's Improve our action at the polls.
Why sUait until just before election time.

Of international and national ag-
onies today. There are strikes,
demonstrations, riots, fights,
massacres and other terrible
deeds occurring at home and
on foreign soil.


Our diplomats have convinced
those who are in power to es-
tablish shot line" from Wash
ington DC. to Moscow. This pri-
vate telephone service is con-
nected directly from our presi-
dent office to the Russian pre-
mier's office. The line is sup
posedly method to prevent hasty
decisions and save time routing
Information through our diplo-
matte corps.


A couple of weeks ago some
person in Finland severed piece
of the hot line connection. just
imagine If there had been dra-
matte and urgent message to con-
vey from Moscow to the White
Housed Can't you see Lyndon
drawing to Nk1ta, "Howdy, Nix
XII, how ya'll been over there7"


Before Nikita would have had
time to answer and get the pro-
per translation back - the wire
would have been severed by an
irate citizen or some irrespon-
sible prankster.


We may marvel at man. at
tempts to conquer space, but
there are many more gremlins
around than the scientists dare to
mention. They are constantly
preparing for the unforeseen or the
problematic or the theoretical
but never, never should the human
element be overlooked.


No mention was made for the
reason of the Firms action. He
merely cut the wire. Perhaps. he
had an unhappy childhood. Per-
chance, his early days we're upset
by the constant ringing of tele-
phone. Maybe he was ignored by
his mother while she conversed
on the telephone.


Instead of hot line there
should be in its place a hot
party line. Why have just one hot
line to the Russians7 What about
a hot line with Great Britain,
France, West and EastGermany,
Greece, Liberia, New Zealand,
Brazil and Antarctica7


This would give our men in
the White House ample instant
coverage of faraway places.


This hot party line would be
connected through some kind of
dual control--no one station could
be interrupted by mere cutting
of the wire. A satellite trans
mitter would no doubt be useful.


In addition the hot line con-
versations should be teleWsed
via the national hookups. Cities
without teleWsion facilities could
hear the phone calls on the ma
tional radio broadcasts.


The international hot party line
would eliminate the vast intelli-
gence and counter intelligence
corps which operate in all ma
tions. This would also halt the
need for the hundreds of foreign
ambassadors, embassy officers
and emissaries of good will who
inhabit the cities across the four
corners Of the earth.


AS the operation became bet
ter controlled there could be a
line connected with all of the
nations represented in the
United Nations. We could save
other thousands by providing all
of our enemies, friends, neutral
allies and our own citizens with
firsthand reports of our foreign
